awd_titl_txt: Seeking Synergy: K-12 Professional Development as a Model for College Science Faculty
awd_abstract_narration:
It is a national priority to produce a well-prepared workforce in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM).  This workforce is needed to make progress in science, to advance national health initiatives, and support overall national prosperity in an increasingly technical economy. One contemporary challenge colleges and universities face in meeting this challenge is the need to provide effective professional development opportunities for faculty members.  For example, professional development could help faculty learn about emerging research related to student learning, and this knowledge could inform teaching practices.  This project aims to serve the national interest by convening professional development leaders from both K-12 and higher education to determine the design principles of a new model of professional development for college science teaching.  This project is designed to draw upon evidence-based, effective professional development practices from the K-12 sector, and to apply these strategies to programs for faculty members teaching undergraduate biology students.  Multiple K-12 models for professional development have been rigorously tested and shown to improve teacher knowledge, skill, and student learning.  This gathering is designed to focus specifically on teaching and learning methods designed to reveal and respond to student thinking.

This project will support a three-day conference to define the design principles of a new professional development program for college biology faculty. The model will derive components from K-12 professional development models and focus on helping faculty learn the pedagogy of revealing and responding to student thinking. The conference will extend the work of two well-established research and professional development groups in STEM education, the Automated Analysis of Constructed Response project (AACR) and the Science Teachers Learning from Lesson Analysis project (STeLLA). AACR focuses on undergraduate science education and addresses: the creation of constructed-response assessments that reveal students' mental models of scientific concepts; the creation of machine learning models to predict experts' scoring of student responses; the production of reports for faculty that describe the computerized analysis of student writing; and long-term, local faculty learning communities that support faculty users of AACR. STeLLA supports K-12 teachers to view their teaching through the lens of student thinking. The efficacy of STeLLA's approach to professional development has been demonstrated through randomized and quasi-experimental studies that link teacher learning with increased student learning. The conference will include members of AACR and STeLLA as well as experts from other higher education and K-12 professional development arenas. The conference will produce a framework for developing a new college biology professional development program, which can be implemented and researched. It also will create a network of science education professional development specialists and researchers from both K-12 and higher education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Professional development programs have proliferated to help college science instructors teach with an emphasis on core concepts and scientific practices. Yet emerging evidence from these programs indicates it is time to consider the next generation of professional development for college science teaching. Many college instructors who participate in professional development continue to focus on what they are teaching rather than what students are learning. These instructors generally do not realize the necessity of listening to their students? ideas during class and responsively guiding students to refine their ideas. The next generation of professional development for college science teaching should help college science instructors focus on student thinking. These new professional development models should draw upon research from K-12 education. Several prominent K-12 professional development programs help instructors learn to structure their classes around eliciting student ideas, making sense of those ideas, and using questions, prompts, and explanations to guide students? ideas. These programs have achieved impressive outcomes, including growth in instructors? pedagogical knowledge and students? learning.

The goal of this project was to host Seeking Synergy, a conference  for professional development experts in K-12 and higher education that would generate principles for the next generation of college science teaching professional development. Conference participants included representatives from several higher education organizations, such as the Automated Analysis of Constructed Response project and the National Institute on Scientific Teaching. Conference participants also included representatives from K-12 education organizations, such as BSCS Science Learning and Ambitious Science Teaching. Participants listened to presentations on professional development research and practice, engaged in discussions and sample K-12 professional development sessions, and collaborated to determine the principles that should be included in college science professional development.   

The key outcomes of the Seeking Synergy Conference were the following ten principles for teaching professional development focused on student thinking (Table 1).

Table 1. Design Principles for professional development in higher education.

Design Principle

Description. PD for higher education must ?

1.     Focus on student thinking

Emphasize students? ideas and practices and consider how instruction can guide students? development of ideas.

2.     Build on a framework that describes how people learn

Articulate a framework that explains how people learn, so instructors can gain better insights to student learning and their own learning.

3.     Articulate learning goals for instructors

Clearly state the goal that college instructors improve their teaching practice.

4.     Involve collective inquiry

Take place in a social environment where instructors can learn from each other and recognize the importance of viewing colleagues as a resource for teaching.

5.     Use data as the basis for claims about students and instructors

Substantiate claims about student thinking and instructor learning with evidence, such as student writing or observations of instructors working with their students.

6.     Analyze teaching practice using videos or other rich, authentic artifacts from the classroom

Bring student learning and teaching to life by reviewing video and other classroom artifacts.

7.     Practice new pedagogies and then get feedback

Provide practical guidance by reviewing and discussing authentic practice, including one?s own practice and the practices of colleagues.

8.     Ensure that PD is a safe space

Create an environment where instructors feel accepted, respected, valued, and  comfortable enough to risk the vulnerability of examining their practice with peers.

9.    Make PD long-term and iterative

Provide enough time and iteration for the slow, effortful work of understanding data, deciding how to act, and reflecting on those actions.

10.  Pay attention to the systems in which instructors work

Acknowledge and work to support instructors who work in departments that undervalue teaching and consider PD as an activity for some but not all.

 

The Seeking Synergy conference had intellectual merit for several reasons. The conference: 1) yielded design principles for a new professional development program based on successful K-12 programs, 2) generated new knowledge about translating evidence-based models between K-12 and higher education contexts; 3) provided a basis for improving evidence-based practice in undergraduate science by improving instructor learning.

The Seeking Synergy conference had multiple broader impacts. 1) The design principles shown in Table 1 can be used by higher education practitioners beyond the project. 2) The conference improved the infrastructure for research and education by seeding a network among higher education and K-12 professional development professionals. This network has the potential to generate research and educational interventions beyond the conference. 3) The conference provided training opportunities for the postdoctoral research associates and graduate students who participated. They benefited from learning how diverse scholars collaborate toward a shared goal. 4) The conference laid the groundwork to shift the teaching practices of numerous science faculty, which in turn can impact thousands of undergraduate science students.
